- Location: Column 5
- Date: Probably Trajan
- [Hieroglyphic Text](https://www.ifao.egnet.net/uploads/publications/enligne/Temples-Esna003.pdf#page=137){target="_blank"}  
- Bibliography: @sauneron-8, pp. 24-27, 64-66. See also [Tempeltexte 2.0](http://www.tempeltexte.uni-tuebingen.de/portal/#/text-detail/1001){target="_blank"}
- Parallels: Multiple epithets occur verbatim in the great hymn to Menhyt: [Esna 251].


<div class="col2">  

^14^ *ỉr(.t) p(ȝ) wdn n Mnḥy.t *  
*m hrw pn mỉ rʿ-nb  *  
*ḏd-mdw  *  

^14^ Performing the litany of Menhyt  
on this day like every day.  
Words spoken:  

</div>

<div class="col2">

^15^ *wdn n Mnḥy.t wr.t  *  
*nb.t ḫnt-tȝ*  
*m rn(.w)=s nb(.w)*  
*ḥr-tp ʿnḫ-wḏȝ-snb  *  
*n nsw.t-bỉty  *  
*(pr-ʿȝ ʿnḫ(.w) ḏ.t)|  *  
  
^15^ Offering for Menhyt the great,   
Lady of Khent-ta,   
in all her names,  
in addition to the life, prosperity, health    
for the King of Upper and Lower Egypt,  
(Pharaoh, living forever)|   

</div>

**60**  
<div class="col2">

*n Mnḥy.t*   
*nb.t ḫnt-tȝ*  
*r-mn pḥw*  
*ḫnt.t sḫ.t*  
   
For Menhyt,     
Lady of Edge of the Earth  
all the way to the Pehus,[^fn-233-1]  
foremost of the Field.

</div>

[^fn-233-1]: ![](./images/233_25_60.png){width=32%} - This epithet occurs in the main Menhyt hymn [Esna 251], 24: ![](./images/251_24_9.png){width=28%}, as well as *Esna* VII, 552, 7: ![](./images/552_7_1.png){width=20%}. Based on the context, the first toponym might not be identical with Khent-ta, the usual cult center of Menhyt, but a homonymous designation for the southern border of Egypt (*Wb* III, 306, 6-7). The location of *ḫnt-tȝ* in Esna has never been established, however, so it is at least theoretically possible that Menhyt's original home was closer to Elephantine.

**69**  
<div class="col2">

*n Mnḥy.t*     
*m bw.w nb.w*   
*mr kȝ=sn ỉm*   
   
^27^ *dỉ=sn ʿnḫ-ḏd-wȝs nb*  
*snb nb*  
*n zȝ-Rʿ*  
*(pr-ʿȝ ʿnḫ(.w) ḏ.t)|*  
*mỉ Rʿ ḏ.t*  
  
For Menhyt,   
in all places,  
where their Kas love to be.[^fn-233-2]  
   
May they give all *ʿnḫ-ḏd-wȝs*,  
all health,   
to the son of Re,  
(Pharaoh living eternally)|  
like Re, forever.  

</div>

[^fn-233-2]: At this point, the hymn switches to the third person plural. Either referring to the many manifestations of Menhyt, or alluding to the duality Menhyt-Nebtu.
